info.game_comments: (Sarah: I'm Sarah of the Clue Crew.  Today on Jeopardy!, everything's fair game.  Stay tuned.)

(1, 1).clue: Carbon dioxide is swapped for oxygen in the alveoli of these organs

(2, 1).clue: She only made it to No. 4 with "Fame", but topped the charts with "Flashdance...What a Feeling"

(3, 1).clue: "Profound" adjective for the part of the "South" stretching from South Carolina to Louisiana

(4, 1).clue: A hacker stole this billionaire's credit card number off the Internet & used it to order Viagra for him

(5, 1).clue: 1960s NBA superstar guard Robertson was known as "The Big" this

(6, 1).clue: It was back to ghoul for John Kassir on HBO's "Tales from" this place

(1, 2).clue: Blood pressure is measured in millimeters of this poisonous metal

(2, 2).clue: In an eerie scene, Dean Stockwell lip-syncs "In Dreams" in this David Lynch film named for another song

(3, 2).clue: A classic 1936 book about the literary peak of Boston & Concord was called "The Flowering of" this area

(4, 2).clue: He authored "Between Hope and History: Meeting America's Challenges for the 21st Century"

(6, 2).clue: Term for a family where dad took off, mom ignores the kids, etc.; Sally Jessy would be jobless without them

(1, 3).clue: When the heart's atria contract, blood flows from the right atrium into the right this

(2, 3).clue: The "Wind Beneath My Wings" is from this weepy Bette Midler-Barbara Hershey film

(3, 3).clue: Geographic collective name for Delaware, Maryland, Missouri & Kentucky from when they refused to secede

(4, 3).clue: Seen here, this actor headed the drama department at Montana State University before his acting career took off

(5, 3).clue: Also standing for a unit of energy, this is the most frequently used letter in printed material in English

(6, 3).clue: I don't mean to do this, but it means to inquire unnecessarily into something, or open it by leverage

(1, 4).clue: The plasma globulin called transferrin transports this ferric material

(2, 4).clue: (Hi, I'm Jane Krakowski of "Ally McBeal".)  Appropriately, this woman sang "Viva Rock Vegas" on the soundtrack to my film "The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas"

(3, 4).clue: It's what PN stands for in PNNL, a national laboratory in Richland, Washington

(4, 4).clue: TV journalist & producer of such PBS series as "Genesis: A Living Conversation"

(5, 4).clue: This letter found in Mr. Thant's name is a Burmese title of respect, meaning "Mister"

(6, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew helps us out.)  The term for a worker in the area seen here is also a 1980 Jodie Foster film

(1, 5).clue: These tiny bits of cytoplasm lacking nuclei are there to gang up in clots

(2, 5).clue: He recorded standards like "It Had to be You" & "Our Love is Here to Stay" for "When Harry Met Sally..."

(3, 5).clue: Thought to be barren, the Great Plains were marked on pre-Civil War maps as "The Great American" this

(4, 5).clue: (Here's Sofia having some fun at the San Diego Zoo.)  This playful bird is not to be confused with the spoonbill, playbill or T-bill

(5, 5).clue: This comes before "Claudius" & "the Jury" in literary works

(6, 5).clue: In physics it pertains to force or power; in comics, it pertains to the "Duo" of Batman & Robin

(1, 1).clue: Derided as the "Pearson Pennant" after the prime minister, it was adopted in 1964

(2, 1).clue: Ahhh...this one really doesn't take me back

(4, 1).clue: His "Pygmalion" includes the line "I shall make a duchess of this draggletailed guttersnipe"

(6, 1).clue: Charles Dickens' Mr. Creakle likes to whack pupils on the hand with this measuring device

(1, 2).clue: Beginning in February 1942, Canada moved 21,000 people of this background to internment camps

(2, 2).clue: It might be Bon Jovi's favorite

(4, 2).clue: Filmed in 2000, it's Doug Wright's play about the Marquis de Sade in an asylum

(6, 2).clue: ( Sarah is tattooing the show's logo on her arm.)  My temporary tattoo uses this dye that's also used to redden hair

(1, 3).clue: In 2000 this party led by Preston Manning, not Pat Buchanan, was absorbed by the New Canadian Alliance

(4, 3).clue: In the '30s Wolfe wrote "You Can't Go Home Again" & Kaufman & Hart wrote "You Can't" do this

(2, 4).clue: By definition, this sign is commonplace
